Comment: The Queen's Fianchetto. To defend against a big White's pawn center and make it more difficult for White to play a c4 pawn break.
Classic move. White is building an advantage through the center.
Bishop development, continuing the Fianchetto development
White often preferred developing his bishop to d3 rather than c4, b5 or Nc3.
Black offers a pawn to break White's pawn center.
White accepts the Pawn, oppening the a8-h1 diagonal for the Bishop.
Check!, This prevent Bishop from taking unprotected h1 tower.
Check!, This prevent Bishop from taking unprotected h1 tower.
Now Black is attacking the White Queen & the White Tower.
Excellent Move!, If Black is ambitious and take White's Tower, it's Checkmate by, 7....  Bxh8  8.gxh7#
Black gets greedy and loses immediately.
Another excellent move!, You can think black have an excellent game...
...happily eating the enemy Queen, but he doesn't see the danger...
Checkmate!, Even after four centuries, some games can still elict a smile. Taken from, Chessmaster 9000, Classic Games; Gioachinno Greco vs Unknown. Annotation from 1619.
